subject: meta-google: gbmc-ncsi-config: Add public address to gbmc-bridge
commitMessage:
meta-google: gbmc-ncsi-config: Add public address to gbmc-bridge

This dynamically detects addresses applied to the NC-SI interface and
infers the addreses which should be used explicitly by BMCs.

Change-Id: I9036be0a54936aace580746cd1900ee653f43cfd
Signed-off-by: William A. Kennington III <wak@google.com>

nit: possibly missing a word - "by" maybe?
Yeah.
What does nos stand for?
No separators, we compute the number of colons in the string by removing them, and comparing the length of the original string to the removed string.
What are these dollar signs for?
It evaluates the content after it, so $'\n' becomes a newline character in the string. Just adding the escape sequence doesn't do the evaluation.
just for readability, should we use == instead of =?
You can't use `==` in posix test, `=` is the only method.
Oh, I didn't realize this kind of conditional statement was supported - does it check that all 3 variables are equal?
Just realized that you have -a here. Ignore this comment.

The script is missing shebang with interpeter.

How those files are being included / called? With "return" statements they have to be either sourced within a function or being executed as a script.

It's not missing a shebang as it is always sourced and can't be run directly.

It gets run as a hook in the gbmc-ip-monitor script when responding to network reconfigurations.

nit:
[ -z "$gbmc_ncsi_mgmt_pub_addr_lib" ] || return

Not sure that it makes sense to use expansion to default value (empty string) over here when variable is unset.
The variable will never exist at the time this is sourced, basically this is an include guard.

Consider to use heredoc:

  read -r -d '' contents <<-EOF
  Address=${pfx}fd01::/128
  IPv6PrefixDelegation=yes

  [IPv6PrefixDelegation]
  RouterLifetimeSec=60
  ...
  LifetimeSec=60

  EOF

later:

  printf "[Network]\n%s" "$contents" >"$file"

I'd still prefer to keep all of the file contents in one variable in case sections get added. I wanted to separate any content generation from writing it out to the file.

Otherwise done.

A bit confused how shell variables are being expanded with single quotes. Is it specific to bitbake expansion? For regular shell, the if_name will always be equal to "${GBMC_NCSI_IF_NAME}" string and follow-up statement will be always false.
`${}` is a bitbake expansion and would need to be escaped to be used in the shell. That's why it's not double quoted.
nit: for readability I would use heredoc + cat here, but it out of scope of this change :)
Yeah, something that could be cleaned up in a future change.
It's better to use global modifier to sed in case if the needle occurs several times in one line. Same for above lines.
Yeah, I only used these references once in any of the files so I didn't really bother with it.
when using "<<-EOF" you can indent the following lines including close statement for heredoc. Leading spaces will be ignored
Should bridging logic just be rolled into phosphor-networkd directly?
It's too opinionated and far too specific to the specifics of how google networking works. The basic concept could possibly be used, but it needs all of the higher level opinions to really be useful.
Same as the previous CL (maybe this is super obvious?) I'm not fully understanding how this works. Could you explain this to me for my knowledge? or would it help if we put a comment here?
Added comments
not sure why this is commented out in the GUI
That's weird, it's not like this with other highlighters.
